title: 114_hr3295
content: The following sums are appropriated for fiscal year 2015 from the Treasury for the Department of Justice, specifically for state and local law enforcement assistance under the Office of Justice Programs. $140,000,000 is allocated for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, with funds designated for various programs including the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, including public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for grants to State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States and $15,000,000 for grants to statewide law enforcement agencies. $15,000,000 is allocated for competitive grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in States with high rates of primary treatment admissions for heroin and other opioids, to be used for investigative purposes related to illicit activities and trafficking. The Small Business Administration receives $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans program account. The Department of Labor's Employment and Training Administration is allocated funds for training and employment services. The Department of Labor receives $265,000,000 for training and employment services, while the Department of Health and Human Services receives $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative under the Public Health Service Act. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives $10,000,000 for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative and additional funding for the community development fund. $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments as grants. Funds will be awarded to distressed communities based on criteria such as racial or income segregation, low employment rates, low college enrollment, poor-performing schools, high infant mortality rates, and vacant homes. The youth aged 17 to 25 in distressed communities face challenges such as poor-performing schools, high infant mortality rates, vacant homes, and proximity to environmentally hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage for infrastructure, housing, and economic revitalization, with criteria for eligibility. The Secretary will specify criteria for fund allocation. The Secretary will specify criteria for approval of revitalization plans in distressed areas within 45 days of enactment. Plans not meeting criteria will be disapproved. Funds allocated will not affect non-emergency formula allocations. Grantees will receive training on grant management. The Secretary will provide grantees with training on grant management, including performance requirements and penalties in contracts. The Secretary may waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations, except for fair housing and nondiscrimination requirements. The Secretary may waive certain requirements for the use of funds, except for fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment, if good cause exists. Up to 30 percent of the funds can be used for technical assistance to provide immediate community response. The funds are allocated for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for necessary costs of administering and overseeing the funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with terms unchanged unless mutually agreed upon. Reserve balances exceeding four months of expenses can be used for agency purposes under the agreement. Moving-to-Work agencies must report financial data to HUD as required by the Secretary to assess policy impact. The Act provides emergency funding designated by Congress, subject to the President's approval. It is known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
